meaning_mnemonic:
<reading>Colle</reading>ct (これ) <vocabulary>this one</vocabulary> right here! Go ahead, collect this one.

You can use これ to talk about anything that's close to you. Things that are close to you are easy to collect, after all!

It's only <reading>through</reading> (する) doing things that we get better at them, so you need <vocabulary>to do</vocabulary> them as much as you can.

する basically means <vocabulary>to do</vocabulary>, but it’s incredibly versatile and goes beyond its English equivalent. Besides being used alone, it can be put together with a whole range of nouns to turn them into verbs. We call these する verbs and you'll learn a lot of them as we go along!

<reading>Ringo</reading> (リンゴ) just ate your <vocabulary>apple</vocabulary>! You were about to take a bite, and he grabbed it. What is Ringo doing snatching apples? Surely he can afford his own.

Did you know that Ringo Starr once appeared in a Japanese TV commercial for <vocabulary>apple</vocabulary> juice? That might help you remember this word, too!

リンゴ is also commonly written in hiragana, and even in kanji, but you’ll probably see it in katakana the most.

コーヒー is the katakana version of the English word <vocabulary>coffee</vocabulary>. 

Just watch out for the second syllable, which changes to ヒー in Japanese.

<reading>Connie Chihua</reading>hua (こんにちは) says <vocabulary>hello</vocabulary>. Connie Chihuahua is an amazing talking chihuahua. She can only say "hello", but that alone is pretty impressive.

こんにちは is a formal way to say "hello". It’s generally used during the daytime, from late morning to early evening. Watch out for the は on the end, which is always pronounced わ.

He <reading>eats</reading> (いつ) and eats and eats. <vocabulary>When</vocabulary> does this guy not eat?

いつ is a question word that is used to ask <vocabulary>when</vocabulary>.
